snippet: Even as Russian officials geared up to address expected accusations of election fraud, installing cameras at polling places, a small army of observers also fanned out to monitor the process on Sunday.
abstract: Thousands of people show up at Russian presidential polling stations, and hundreds of thousands watch ballot boxes via Internet, to monitor the voting process, after evidence of brazen violations during parliamentary elections in December; Kremlin seems better prepared to counter accusations, which are seen as potentially undermining to Prime Min Vladimir V Putin, and accuse monitors of fabricating reports of fraud.

byline.original: By ELLEN BARRY and SOPHIA KISHKOVSKY
byline.contributor: Michael Schwirtz, Olga Slobodchikova and Glenn Kates contributed reporting.

lead_paragraph: Even as Russian officials geared up to address expected accusations of election fraud, installing cameras at polling places, a small army of observers also fanned out to monitor the process on Sunday.

headline.seo: Russian Vote Draws Thousands of Election Observers
headline.main: Russian Turnout Includes Thousands of Eager Election Observers
headline.print_headline: Russian Turnout Includes Thousands of Eager Election Observers
